page.pageintro: A variable is a container for storing a value, like a number we can use in a calculation, or a string we might use within a sentence.

content.label: SECTION
content.heading: Declaring a variable
copy: To use a variable you've first got to create it, or more accurately, we call this declaring the variable. To do this, we use the keyword var followed by the name you want to call the variable. The name of the variable is often called the identifier.

Here we are creating two variables called myName and myAge. The variables declared have no value; they are empty containers. A variable without any value is an undefined variable. When you enter the variable names in the console, you should get a value of undefined returned.
To assign a value to a variable - also known as initializing a value - we use the assignment operator (=). When the variable name is used within the console, the value will be returned.
If the variable does not exist, you'll get an error message.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
SECTION
copy: You can declare variables using the keywords of: var, let or const. As long as a variable is not declared as a constant - using the const keyword - you can change it's value. A variable declared as a constant should have it's name in uppercase. This is a general convention.

content.label: SECTION
content.heading: Updating values
copy: Once a variable has been initialized with a value, you can change (or update) the value by providing it a different value. Let's change the value of myName to 'Bob'.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
SECTION
content.heading: Data types
copy: Unlike some other languages, you don't need to specify what data type (e.g. numbers, strings, arrays, etc) a variable will contain. This is because JavaScript is a 'loosely types language'. For example, if you declare a variable and give it a value within quotes (double or single), the browser will treat the variable as a string.
